answers: obesity [or obese; prompt on overweight]
leptin
brown fat [or brown adipose tissue; or BAT]
parts: Name this condition which is classified as “excessive fat accumulation which presents a risk to health” according to the WHO. People with a BMI over 30 have this condition.
Mice have been shown to exhibit the obese phenotype if they are deficient in this hormone which promotes satiety by acting on lateral receptors in the hypothalamus.

A therapy that is currently being explored to combat obesity involves the stimulation of this heavily energy expending tissue which, unlike its leptin producing counterpart, contains multilocular fat droplets and highly expresses thermogenin.

answers: films [accept movies, motion pictures, or other equivalents like the plots to films; prompt on plots] (the characters are Molina and Valentin)
Juan Manuel Puig Delledonne
Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina]
parts: Name these things. In another novel, five of them are described in detail by a transgender woman to a leftist revolutionary in their shared prison cell.
Kiss of the Spider Woman and Betrayed By Rita Hayworth are both novels by this author, who also wrote about Big Fanny and Juan Carlos Etchepare in Heartbreak Tango.
Puig was an author from this South American country, which was also the birthplace of gaucho literature.

answers: Parsifal
Richard Wagner
leitmotifs [or leading motifs; prompt on motifs]
parts: Name this opera. At the end of this opera, the evil sorcerer Klingsor throws a spear at the title character, who uses it to draw a cross.
Parsifal was written by this German composer of the Ring Cycle.

Like Wagner's other operas, Parsifal makes extensive use of these musical ideas that can represent a character, object, or emotion. The most famous of these themes, from Tristan und Isolde, contains the "Tristan chord" and represents desire.

answers: Suriname [or Surinam; or Republic of Suriname; or Republiek Suriname]
English Civil Wars [or First English Revolution; or British Civil Wars; or Wars of the Three Kingdoms; or Second English Civil War; prompt on Great Rebellion; prompt on Civil Wars]
Aphra Behn
parts: The colony, whose democratic experiment was ended by Governor William Byam, was based in this modern-day country in South America. The Dutch gained control of this country in exchange for ceding rights to New York.
The colony was founded by and named for a man fleeing from this conflict. Following this Old World conflict, Oliver Cromwell became Lord Protector.
This author and vigorous enemy of the Whig party based the novella Oroonoko (“or-uh-NO-ko”) on experience gained living in Willoughbyland.

answers: e e cummings [or edward estlin cummings]
rain [accept sun moon stars rain]
"i carry your heart with me" [accept any answer that mentions the speaker is carrying the recipient's heart; prompt on carrying]
parts: Name this American poet of the love poem "somewhere i have never travelled gladly beyond," which ignores proper punctuation and capitalization.

cummings ended that poem by noting that not even this thing has hands as small as his lover. In a repeated four-word phrase from "anyone lived in a pretty how town," this word follows the words "sun moon stars."

Another cummings poem says that this fact is "the root of the root and the bud of the bud." A description is acceptable for this fact, which is followed by the parenthetical statement that the speaker does it in his heart.

answers: high-frequency trading [or HFT; or high-speed trading; accept any answer that involves trading stocks or other financial instruments at high speed; prompt on stock trading]
baseball [accept MLB or major league baseball]
microwave transmission [or microwave radio network; do not accept satellite transmissions]
parts: Identify this specific type of algorithmic economic activity, widely blamed for the Flash Crash of 2010.
Michael Lewis, who wrote about high-frequency trading in Flash Boys, is perhaps best known for Moneyball, a book about an Oakland team in this sport.

Transmissions that use this part of the EM spectrum have replaced slower fiber optic links in high frequency trading. TV broadcasters largely switched from this line-of-sight tech to satellite links in the 1960s.

answers: phosphate fertilizers [accept single or triple superphosphate fertilizers]
eutrophication [accept dystrophication, hypertrophication or cultural eutrophication]
dissolved oxygen [or O2]
parts: Name these substances given NPK labels. The gypsum waste from producing these substances must be stored permanently because it off-gasses radon.
Most fertilizer ends up in nearby bodies of water due to agricultural runoff, where its high nutrient load causes this process and produces algal blooms.
The resultant plankton growth depletes this gas from the water, producing hypoxic dead zones which cover thousands of square miles of the Gulf of Mexico.

answers: Chinese civil service examination [or Chinese imperial examination; accept equivalents like Chinese civil service; or keju]
badges [or plaques; or pins; accept Chairman Mao badges]
Joseon dynasty [or Choson dynasty; or Chosun dynasty]
parts: Identify these tests that might have granted one a position as a provincial official.

From the Ming era, the rank of a civil servant could be identified by the type of bird depicted on one of these objects. During the Cultural Revolution, landowners were prohibited from wearing mass-produced aluminum examples of these items depicting Chairman Mao.
Jo Gwangjo tried to make the Korean version of the imperial examination more practical during this final Korean dynasty.

answers: birds [accept Concerto for Birds and Orchestra]
Finland [or Republic of Finland; or Suomi]
Oliver Messiaen [or Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen]
parts: Name these animals that appear in the subtitle of and are heavily featured throughout Cantus Arcticus by Einojuhani Rautavaara (“AY-no-yoo-ha-nee ROUT-ah-var-ah”).
Rautavaara is a composer from this country. Another composer from this country, Jean Sibelius, was inspired by the mythology of the Kalevala to compose The Swan of Tuonela.
Birds inspired a clarinet solo in the “Abyss of the Birds” section of Quartet for the End of Time, which is by this French composer.

answers: Osiris
Pan
Dumuzid [accept Tammuz]
parts: This Egyptian god of the dead was decapitated by his brother Set. This god’s consort, Isis, collected the pieces of his body and brought him back to life.
A divine voice supposedly revealed news of this god’s death to a sailor. This god also lost a music contest judged by Tmolus.

The report of Pan’s death may have been a misinterpretation of worshipers proclaiming the death of this Mesopotamian deity. For failing to mourn the death of his wife Inanna, this god of shepherds was dragged into the underworld, where he remains for half of each year.

answers: Noël Coward
Blithe Spirit
Percy Shelley
parts: Name this British playwright who wrote about the actor Garry Essendine in Present Laughter, which was originally titled Sweet Sorrow.
The medium Madame Arcati summons the ghost of Charles Condomine's dead wife Elvira in this play by Coward.

Blithe Spirit takes its title from the poem "To a Skylark" by this earlier author, who also wrote the play Prometheus Unbound. The title figure commands, "Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!" in this author's poem "Ozymandias."

answers: engines [or heat engines; or internal-combustion engine]
compression [or adiabatic compression; accept compression ratio]
Albert Einstein
parts: Identify these machines whose ideal form was formulated by Sadi Carnot. A real one of these machines was designed by Rudolf Diesel.

In the Carnot cycle, the heat sink receives the heat rejected by the engine at low temperature during this process. In diesel engines, a ratio named for this stage is usually between 14-to-1 and 22-to-1.
Unlike normal thermodynamic cycle-based refrigerators, the constant-pressure refrigerator designed by this scientist and Leo Szilard requires only a heat source and water, ammonia and butane.

answers: Congress of Vienna [or Vienna Congress of 1814; prompt on Concert of Europe]
alcohol [or beer; or ale] (the festival is Oktoberfest)
Esperanto
parts: Identify this meeting which was the subject of the doctoral dissertation of Henry Kissinger.

Merchants in the Akwizgran Discrepancy did business smuggling this stuff into Holland. A festival centered around this stuff in Munich began as a celebration of the wedding of the future King Ludwig I in 1810.

Dr. Wilhelm Molly and others hoped to establish the Akwizgran Discrepancy as Amikejo (“ah-mee-KAY-yo”), the first state to speak this language created by L. L. Zamenhof (“ZAH-men-hof”). It's the world's most popular artificial language.

answers: Gertrude Stein (The poster portrait is by Charles Demuth.)
Henri Matisse [or Henri Émile Benoît Matisse]
Le Corbusier [or Charles-Édouard Jeanneret]
parts: Identify this woman who amassed a notable art collection with her brother Leo. A poster portrait of this artist features the word "LOVE" several times.
Stein once owned this artist's Woman with a Hat. This artist of The Joy of Life founded the Fauve movement.
This architect designed the Villa Stein for Gertrude's sister-in-law Sarah. He outlined his views on architecture in his book Towards a New Architecture.

answers: Hermann Ebbinghaus
memory
working memory [prompt on primary memory]
parts: Identify this German psychologist who formulated the "forgetting curve."
Ebbinghaus studied this mental faculty, which is divided into short-term and long-term types.

Some scholars draw a distinction between short-term memory and this related form of memory, which has a visuo-spatial component according to a model by Alan Baddeley. Other theories hold that this form of memory can be manipulated, unlike short-term memory.

answers: Caroline Affair
Daniel Webster
Aroostook War [or Pork and Beans War]
parts: Name this event where British soldiers crossed into American territory and sent a ship they suspected of aiding William Lyon Mackenzie over Niagara Falls.

This Massachusetts Senator signed a treaty with Baron Ashburton that eased tensions in the wake of the Caroline Affair. This longtime senator formed the "Great Triumvirate" with John C. Calhoun and Henry Clay.
The Webster-Ashburton treaty also settled a boundary dispute between Maine and New Brunswick which had resulted in this conflict, whose only casualties were two Canadian lumberjacks.

answers: potatoes [do not accept "sweet potato"]
hermit crabs [or Paguroidea; accept coconut crabs or robber crabs; prompt on crabs or crustaceans]
mustard [accept mustard seeds or mustard plant or the Parable of the Mustard Seed]
parts: Identify this food that was long considered dangerous by Europeans. By the 19th century, it had fatefully become a staple food of Ireland.

The largest of these creatures, also the world's largest arthropod, can exert 3,300 newtons of pressure to break open coconuts but are in danger of extinction because their flesh is considered to be an aphrodisiac.
This other aphrodisiac plant grows from an extremely small seed, inspiring Jesus's parable about the Kingdom of Heaven.

answers: "The Snow Queen" [or Snedronningen]
the ugly duckling [or Den grimme ælling; prompt on duckling]
"The Little Match Girl" [or Den Lille Pige med Svovlstikkerne]
parts: Name this tale in which Gerda meets the little robber girl on a journey through Lapland to save Kai from the title character.
In another Hans Christian Andersen tale, this title character becomes trapped in ice during a bitterly cold winter, shortly after which he discovers that he was a swan all along.
The title child of this third Andersen tale meets her grandmother in heaven after freezing to death on New Years' Eve.

answers: Enoch [or Chanok; or Henok]
St. Jude [or Judas Thaddaeus or Lebbaeus; prompt on Judas]
Book of Daniel
parts: Name this father of Methuselah. In the Book of Genesis, he is said to have "walked with God, and he was not, for God took him."
This saint's epistle quotes from the non-canonical Book of Enoch, "Behold, the Lord comes with ten thousands of his holy ones." He is venerated as a patron saint of lost causes.
In this book, a "Watcher" commands Nebuchadnezzar to cut down a tree and bind its stump in a dream. This book's namesake prophet is thrown into the lions' den by Darius the Mede.

answers: leaving groups
fluorine [or F]
Frederick Sanger [accept Sanger sequencing]
parts: Name these species which form through cleavage. The first step of an SN1 reaction forms a carbocation and one of these species.

parts: Name this Bahamanian-American actor. He became the first African-American to win the Academy Award for Best Actor with his role in Lilies of the Field.

Poitier was the first African-American to win a competitive Oscar since Hattie McDaniel. McDaniel won her Oscar for playing Scarlett O’Hara’s slave in this 1939 film adaptation of a Margaret Mitchell novel.
Sidney Poitier played Virgil Tibbs in In the Heat of the Night, a man with this profession. In another film, a character with this profession finds a man using a woodchipper in the woods.
